dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Well, yeah, uh, some things. You know, military comms resumed, some fentanyl stuff looks promising.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Well, yeah, uh, some things. You know, military comms resumed, some fentanyl stuff looks promising.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Notably, the two countries will resume military-to-military communication, thereby reducing the chances of an accidental conflict, and China will do more to restrict the export of chemicals used to make the powerful synthetic opioid fentanyl a major cause of death in the United States.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: But not, like, everything? What about those, uh, tariffs? That's still a mess, isn't it?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: But not, like, everything? What about those, uh, tariffs? That's still a mess, isn't it?

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Exactly. Tariffs were, um, totally elusive. No real progress there.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Exactly. Tariffs were, um, totally elusive. No real progress there.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: But there is one crucial area where progress remained elusive: tariffs.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Remind me, like, how bad did it get? With Trump, I mean.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Remind me, like, how bad did it get? With Trump, I mean.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Okay, so, in 2018, Trump, uh, hiked them from about three percent to over twenty-one percent.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Okay, so, in twenty eighteen, Trump, uh, hiked them from about three percent to over twenty-one percent.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: In 2018, then-US President Donald Trumps administration hiked the tariff rate on imports from China from slightly over 3% to more than 21% a level unseen in the US since before World War II.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Twenty-one percent? Wow. So China just, like, took that?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Twenty-one percent? Wow. So China just, like, took that?

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: No, no. China retaliated, increasing theirs on US goods from eight percent to about nineteen percent.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: No, no. China retaliated, increasing theirs on U S goods from eight percent to about nineteen percent.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: This prompted China to retaliate with higher tariffs on US imports from about 8% to some 19%.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: And that, like, hurts us, right? Not just them?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: And that, like, hurts us, right? Not just them?

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Oh, absolutely. Every serious study shows those increased costs were, um, passed right to American consumers.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Oh, absolutely. Every serious study shows those increased costs were, um, passed right to American consumers.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Every serious study of the issue suggests that the increased costs arising from the tariffs have been passed onto American consumers.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: So, like, I'm paying more for, uh, everything?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: So, like, I'm paying more for, uh, everything?

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Pretty much. And it's not just finished goods. Think parts, components. Input costs go up for US businesses, too.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Pretty much. And it's not just finished goods. Think parts, components. Input costs go up for U S businesses, too.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: About 40% of US imports from China are parts, components, and intermediate goods, so removing the Trump tariffs would also lower input costs for American service providers and manufacturers.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: So it's, like, actually costing jobs here?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: So it's, like, actually costing jobs here?

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Brookings suggests over a million manufacturing jobs, actually.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Brookings suggests over a million manufacturing jobs, actually.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: A million? Jeez. So, removing them would, um, help, obviously?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: A million? Jeez. So, removing them would, um, help, obviously?

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Massively. Lower cost of living, like, permanently, by about a percentage point. Thatâ€™s, uh, over $250 billion a year in household income.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Massively. Lower cost of living, like, permanently, by about a percentage point. That's, uh, over two hundred fifty dollars billion a year in household income.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Taken together, these effects would permanently reduce the cost of living to Americans by about one percentage point. Put another way, this would be equivalent of an increase in US household income by more than $250 billion per year (1% of US GDP in 2022).

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Then why, uh, why aren't they just, like, getting rid of them? Biden, I mean.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Then why, uh, why aren't they just, like, getting rid of them? Biden, I mean.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Well, you know, the US Trade Rep wasn't even at the summit. Biden's facing pressure from, uh, anti-China factions.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Well, you know, the U S Trade Rep wasn't even at the summit. Biden's facing pressure from, uh, anti-China factions.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: And yet, despite the benefits that reducing tariffs would bring, the US Trade Representative did not attend the San Francisco summit, suggesting that Biden never intended to discuss the issue at all. It is said that Biden does not want to give the Republicans a reason to say that he is soft on China.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: He's worried about looking, um, soft on China, right? For the elections?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: He's worried about looking, um, soft on China, right? For the elections?

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Exactly. But voters care about the cost of living. This is, uh, a clear way to help them.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Exactly. But voters care about the cost of living. This is, uh, a clear way to help them.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Biden is facing a highly contentious election next year, and the rising cost of living is voters number one economic concern.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: So, like, it's a political misstep then?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: So, like, it's a political misstep then?

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: You could say that. Not communicating these benefits is, um, really a failure of leadership.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: You could say that. Not communicating these benefits is, um, really a failure of leadership.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: But he should communicate to voters that removing the Trump tariffs would be good for American households and firms. Not doing so is a failure of leadership.
